Various search strings like "Intrusion detection in VANET/VANET Cloud" has been used for searching of papers. A complete list of search strings used is mentioned in Table III. Exclusion criteria used at different stages are described in Fig. 5. We also applied individual searches on some journals of Springer, Wiley, Taylor and Francis, Science Direct, and so forth to cross-check the e-search.

div.head: E. Data Extraction
div.p: Extracting relevant data from the available research articles is a very crucial and sensitive task. Various authors whenever required were contacted for finding the in-depth knowledge of the research. To avoid biasing at research worker`s end, the review process involving extraction of relevant information from all the 25 considered research papers was done by one author and finalized by another author by discussions, reviews and iteration methods.
The following procedure for data extraction was used in our review:

• The relevant outcome from each of 25 research papers on IDS in VANET was extracted after an in-depth review. • Review outcomes were verified and cross-checked by other authors, and if there were any conflict, then a meeting was called to resolve the issue.

div.head: F. Study and analysis of References in the Article
div.p: A study of articles in term of a number of citation of an article has also been done in this review. The number of times a research article has been cited and referenced is taken as a factor to decide whether to reject or to accept and study the article. Also, other factor like whether the article is published in a journal, conference, a book chapter, a thesis is used for inclusion and exclusion of an article.

Based on the study, it has been found that out of 25 considered article, only 1 papers have 0 citations, while for 2 articles, the citation metric is not available. Also, no work is found related to the use of IDS in VANET Cloud. It is also evident from the graph in Fig. 4

div.head: 1) Distributed and Individual Node IDS (Decentralized IDS)
div.p: Distributed and decentralized based IDS involves deployment of IDS on all or some of the nodes as shown via Fig. 7. Since nodes in VANET are vehicles and are mostly resource-constrained. So deployment of heavy and complex IDS can lead to resource exhaustion of that node and thus there is a need of lightweight but efficient IDS capable of detecting malevolent attacks with minimal resource consumption. For dealing with the above issues, [20], [4] has presented a distributed lightweight IDSs. [20] is capable of dealing with both internal as well as external attack using the set of rules instead of using complex computation based IDS and to reduce the false positive and improve the detection accuracy, Vehicular Behavior Estimation (VBE) is also proposed in which each monitored vehicles are assigned certain malicious level according to the type of attacks they generate. IDS in [4], in turn, via information exchange among multiple layers i.e. between the physical layer and network layer, MAC layer and Network layer, and between physical, MAC and Routing layers detect and isolates the threat. At the physical layer, each node is assigned with a signature key and every message is multiplied by it. Maximum likelihood approach is used to test the message for legitimateness. At MAC layer, monitored nodes are checked for RTS and CTS message while at the network layer, the watchdog is deployed to overhear the exchanged packets. Information exchange between different layers improves the detection rate of the IDS. A similar distributed cross-layer based IDS has been proposed by authors in [1] in which authors have suggested the deployment of different IDS modules collecting audit data from different layers in all the nodes.

Addressing the resource limitations of the vehicles, another lightweight and in-vehicle IDS has been proposed in [16] for CAN network. Both signature and anomaly feature has been incorporated into the vehicles for the detection of intrusion. The proposed IDS uses the time analysis of received CAN message for the detection of any intrusion and claims to work with zero false positives. However, this distributed IDS is designed to detect only injecting based attacks.

Another distributed and individual node deployed IDS has been proposed by authors in [2] in which each vehicle are equipped with a lightweight IDS independent of any infrastructure and expensive hardware like RSUs. This IDS make use of the statistical method for detection of malicious nodes. This approach requires cooperation among other nodes for the exchange of traffic information.

Similar distributed based IDS has been proposed in [7] which uses both signature as well as anomaly detection for countering DDOS attack on VANETs. The IDS component is deployed on each node to detect any malicious behavior as well as the malicious nodes in the network. The installed IDS component monitors the behavior of every other node to check if it is trying to prevent access to any resource of the network. Although monitoring of every other node can lead to extra-burden on the resource constraint node, but simulation result claims to provide high detection and low false positive rate. The Same author has come up with a similar variation of distributed IDS in [10] where ANN based IDS is used and deployed on the vehicles for the detection of DOS attack.

A Similar distributed deployed IDS using deep neural network has been presented in [5] for CAN bus network in which the IDS is deployed in some specialized node but because of the broadcasting nature of the considered CAN bus network, IDS can be integrated into all the nodes also in distributed fashion. The proposed IDS claims to provide realtime detection along with enhancement in the detection rate in CAN bus.

Another distributed and every vehicle deployed IDS using artificial neural network along with Proportional Overlapping Scores (POS) for optimal feature selection from the traffic traces has been proposed in [13]. Instead of deploying the IDS on the RSU or on any specialized nodes, the proposed IDS is deployed on every vehicle to provide continuous protection against potential threats even when the no RSU is in the surroundings.

Distributed IDS sometimes works independently on their own using their own set of attack rules while some variation requires cooperation from other nodes and monitoring of other nodes for its efficient working and detection accuracy [64]. A node that monitors its neighboring nodes is called as watchdog node. [25,29,35,38] are some distributed watchdog based solutions in which watchdog are deployed in every node, and these nodes monitor the activity of their neighbor nodes or in case of them acting as intermediate nodes. A variation of distributed watchdog based IDS can be seen in [23,24,38], where instead of all nodes only some of the nodes are made as watchdogs.

Advantage: No single point of failure, Low network congestion and simple in design and deployment. Disadvantage: These IDS type introduce an extra burden on both nodes as well as network. Special optimization and lightweight IDS need to be used in this deployment strategy as the nodes in VANETs are resource constrained. Also, cooperative version of this IDS introduces extra overhead into the network as information needs to be exchanged between the nodes for IDS working.

div.head: 2) Centralized RSU based IDS
div.p: In this variation, IDS are deployed in a centralized component called as RSU. This type of IDS has a benefit over the distributed individual node based IDS as unlike former nodes, RSU is not resource constrained and thus high power IDS with high accuracy, and more capability can be used in the VANET. Advantage: Deployment location of IDS in this type of IDS are not resource constrained. Disadvantage: RSUs are not uniformly deployed in the VANETs. Rural area has less RSU density compared to urban areas and thus can affect the performance of the IDS. Also in RSU based IDS, all the information need to pass through the RSU for analyzing the traffic and for the detection of malicious nodes, in dense network scenarios this can lead to RSU overwhelming and leading to performance degradation. Also, the centralized IDS may have difficulty in monitoring the nodes during an attack that compromises part of the network [64].

div.head: 3) Centralized Cluster Head Deployed IDS
div.p: In this IDS type, Cluster head nodes of every cluster in the network are made as IDS as illustrated in Fig. 9. This deployment strategy has an advantage over decentralized and centralized RSU based IDS in terms of low network congestion and continuous protection against intruders even in no RSU and remote areas. Also, nodes in VANET are highly mobile and frequently changes their locations making it difficult to monitor, store and analyze their behavior. So all aforesaid issues with real-time IDS deployment and monitoring get overcome by the CH deployed IDS technique.

A Centralized CH deployed IDS scheme has been proposed in [8] where the CHs first operate as watchdogs to monitor and collect data related to the behavior of the MPR nodes which is then further used by the SVM based IDS to check the node for maliciousness. On detection of a node as malicious, the information of it is circulated to the CHs of other clusters. This CH based deployment strategy solves the problem of detection issues due to high mobility of the nodes.

Advantage: Less network congestion, as CH already has all the information of the whole cluster and thus making it as IDS reduces the disadvantage of Distributed individual node IDS. Disadvantage: In dense network scenarios, this IDS deployment strategy suffers from high detection time and low detection rate. Also, the extra responsibility of IDS on the resource constrained CH node can affect the performance of the CH and eventually hampers the whole network performance.

div.head: 4) Hybrid IDS placement
div.p: Hybrid location positioned IDS is formed by clubbing the features of both Centralized and Distributed IDS to take advantage of their good points and avoids the limitations. Hybrid location positioned IDS are both distributed as well as centralized. IDS are deployed in both, all and some individual nodes as well as on the Centralized components like RSU, Cluster head, etc. also as shown in Fig. 10.

A hybrid location deployed IDS has been proposed in [14] in which the three layers of IDS is used based upon their deployment location: Local Intrusion Detection System (LIDS) in which the IDS is deployed on each vehicle in the cluster, Global Intrusion Detection System (GIDS) in which the IDS deployment is done on the Cluster Head (CH) of every cluster and finally a Global Decision System (GDS) in which IDS is deployed on the RSUs. For efficient and accurate detection of intruders from the network, signature based IDS and hybrid Fig. 10. Hybrid Deployed IDS based IDS (signature + anomaly) are used by LIDS and GIDS respectively. LIDS monitors its neighbor nodes for maliciousness and information about the suspected malicious node is passed to the GIDS which further verifies that suspected node for maliciousness and final decision to isolate the node is taken by the GDS only. Advantage: Hybrid version of this IDS enhances the detection rate as well as the detection accuracy as the intrusion is crosschecked by different layers of IDS deployments. Disadvantage: Adds extra delay in malicious node detection by adding multiple intrusion validations which can lead to disastrous results in delay sensitive VANETs.

div.head: B. Detection Techniques
div.p: IDS for VANET and VANET Cloud are classified into six categories based on the type of detection technique used in the system for the detection of threats: Signature based, Watchdog based, Anomaly based, Hybrid, Cross-Layer based and Honeypot based proactive IDS. The comparison of these techniques is explained in tabular form in Table V.
The main aim of this section is to understand how these techniques have been used to develop IDSs for VANET and VANET Cloud.

div.head: 1) Signature based IDS Approaches
div.p: Signature based Intrusion detection approaches also known by names like misused based approaches and rule based detection system detects the malicious nodes and attacks generated by such nodes by matching their signature against the predefined database of signatures and in case of a match, an alarm is generated by the IDS. However, Signature based approaches are capable of detecting only those attacks whose signature is defined in the signature database. Any modification in attack pattern makes the IDS incapable of detecting the attack. Also, Signature based IDS are not capable of detecting zero-day attacks, and the rule database needs to be regularly updated to deal with the newer emerging attacks.

Deployment of Signature based IDS in VANET is a complex task as it is difficult to have predefined rules for the possible VANET attacks. Also, the Network administrator requires modeling the malicious attack pattern for the detection of Future attacks [63].

Due to aforesaid problems, not many signature based approaches have been adopted so far for the detection of intrusions in VANET. However, most of the signature based IDS in literature follows the watchdog approach in which certain specific nodes are assigned the task of monitoring the packets flowing in the network.

Efficient and Lightweight IDS for VANET (ELIDV) is a rule based IDS proposed by authors in [20] which use set of attack signatures for the detection of 3 type of attacks: Sybil attack, Blackhole attack and False Information alert attack. ELIDV is capable of addressing both internal and external attacks and is deployed on each vehicle. Vehicle Behavior Evaluation (VBE) is used along with the Signature based IDS • High False Positive Rate • High overhead and computational cost.
• Difficult to identify the type of attack taking place.
• High detection time and delay • Requires huge training and optimal features for higher accuracy.
• Weak profile accuracy due to frequent change in observed events.

• Unavailable during behavior profiles updation and rebuilding • Consumes more energy • Generates extra overhead over the network by monitoring, analyzing and sharing information across multiple layers. • Efficiency and performance degrades with increase in high mobility nodes [12].

div.head: Hybrid based IDS
div.p: • Capable to detect known as well as unknown attacks with low false positives and detection errors.

• High Computational Cost In order to mitigate the various integrity violation and authenticity based attacks, another rule based IDS solution called REST-Net has been proposed by authors in [21]. REST-Net`s detection engine monitors and analyzes the data using extended plausibility check for the identification of fake message attacks. The plausibility check in REST-Net performs both Pre-validation as well as Post-validation by validating both the Beacons broadcast before and after a particular warning messages. Set of dynamic and static rules adaptive to the realtime traffic conditions are used by the IDS for the detection of malicious events. For enhancing the driving experience of the drivers because of frequent interruptions due to malicious event detection, adaptive warning levels are used, and on the detection of any fake message, the fake message revocation is done. For evaluating the performance of REST-Net, simulations are performed using VANET-Simulator on microtraffic simulator and maps of Berlin, New York, and Puebla. Advantage: Plausibility check using dynamic rules perform both pre and post validation of beacon message and thus improves the detection rate. Also, adaptive warning levels are used for better driver experience even in fake message attack scenarios. Fake messages detected by the detection engine are removed from the network. Disadvantage: The proposed IDS addresses only one attack i.e. fake message injection attack. Also, it is not capable of detecting new attacks automatically. Future Scope: Ways of sharing the REST-Net data and alerts between vehicles can be studied which will help in improving the detection rate of IDS but will also lead to new attacks detection. Also, for improving the REST-Net detection rate, REST-NET IDS can be combined with other existing OSI layer IDS modules.

A signature based IDS is proposed by authors in [18] that uses plausibility model for vehicle movement data. The proposed IDS is capable of identifying a single fake vehicle using the plausibility model even if it uses a valid movement. The IDS is used for detection of two type of attackers: a) roadside attackers performing faked traffic congestion attack and b) attackers in the attempt of denying the real congestion by insertion of moving vehicles into the network. Plausibility clause model has been used in the proposed solution as a rule for the signature based IDS to make sure that no two vehicles intersect each other or on top of each other. Also, a trust model to identify the source of the attack along with the attack is proposed. Disadvantage: Designed to detect only two attacks: a) fake congestion and b) denying existence of congestion. Also, the attack rule for the above two attacks are static, so a small change in the pattern of attack can make them undetectable. Future: In its present state, the proposed IDS is only capable of identifying the fake congestion attack. It is not able to identify the attackers performing that attacks. So in future versions, solutions to identify the source of the attacks will be done.

div.head: 2) Watchdog based IDS in VANETs
div.p: In this special variation of IDS, some nodes are assigned the task of monitoring other nodes in its vicinity for the purpose of detection of any malicious activities performed by them. The node made as watchdog works in promiscuous mode and overhear all the traffic flowing through the network.

If any node, say A, has to send a packet to destination node, say D, and say path between node A and node D has intermediate nodes B and C. Then the source node A will first send the packet to node B which then forwards the same packet to node C while keeping a copy of the packet with it. Now, node B will monitor the node C`s activity whether it forwards the packet to destination node D or not. If node C drops the packet destined for node D, then node C is declared as malicious. Similarly, node B also checks the node C whether it retransmits the packet passed to it or not. If the packet is retransmitted by node C, then also node C is marked as malicious.

However, Watchdog technique is believed to incur more energy and resources as the watchdog nodes are required to overhear all the packets in the promiscuous mode. So to reduce the challenge of excessive resource consumption by watchdog nodes need to be handled during the design and deployment of watchdog mechanism. Also, the watchdog is believed to deal with greedy driver and selfish node attacks only.

Authors in [35] have proposed an IDS based on watchdog for the detection of the selfish nodes performing malicious Fig. 11. Bayesian Filter based Watchdog for detection of Selfish nodes activities for their own benefits. In this approach, every node is equipped with watchdog component for the monitoring and verification of the neighboring nodes to check whether they forward the packet to the next node or not. Because of high mobility in VANET, there are chances of nodes to drop the packet. That node can also be marked as malicious by the watchdog. So for improving the detection accuracy of the proposed IDS, Bayesian filter technique is used along with the watchdog. So after the detection of any node as malicious by the watchdog, Bayesian watchdog keeps a check on the detected node for certain time interval. If the maliciousness of the node under consideration exceeds a certain defined threshold, then that node is declared as malicious. Advantage: Simulation results claims that this version of watchdog based IDS has high detection accuracy and low false positive rate. Disadvantage: This is capable of detecting selfish nodes only which are performing malicious network activities like packet dropping for their own benefits. Also, this technique has no control over the detected selfish and malicious nodes as explained in Fig. 11. Proposed Watchdog based IDS only detects the malicious node and do not isolate the malicious node from taking part in future communication. Also, no information is provided regarding the simulation parameters and node density. Future: This approach can be extended by using various other security approaches along with it to deal with other attacks also.

Authors in [22] have come with a cooperative watchdog based IDS proposal for dealing with selfish and misbehaving nodes in Vehicular Delay Tolerant Networks (VDTNs). In this approach, a greedy node is differentiated from the normal node in such a way that a node with reputation value less than 20 and that drops the packets immediately upon receiving them at least once. The whole proposed system works by cooperative exchange of other node`s reputation values and also by use of classification, neighbor`s evaluation and a decision module for the detection and isolation of selfish node from the network. For the evaluation of the proposed watchdog based IDS, VDTNSim Simulator is used and Spray and Wait routing protocol is used for the routing of the packets. Advantage: Detects as well as isolate the detected selfish node. Simulation results show that the proposed system not only detects the selfish nodes efficiently but also improves the network performance by raising the packet delivery ratio and reducing the resource wastage by decreasing the packet drops. Disadvantage: Works against the selfish nodes only. It is not mentioned about its capability to detect the malicious nodes performing a plethora of VANET attacks. Future Work: Extending the existing Cooperative Watchdog System by enabling the cooperative exchange of information like packet forwarding errors, no. of corrupted packets forwarded, node energy, etc. for the creation of optimal monitoring and management system to detect the network anomalies.

Another watchdog based approach has been adopted by authors in [29] for detection of selfish and misbehaving nodes. Quality of Service Optimized Link State Routing (QOS-OLSR) protocol has been used as routing protocol. A two-phase motivational approach has been used by the author which is able to motivate the malicious nodes to behave normally and cooperatively by giving incentives in the form of reputation which gets linked to the network`s service during the formation of the cluster and detect the selfish misbehaving nodes after the cluster formation. For the detection of selfish misbehaving nodes, Dempster-Shafer based cooperative watchdog is used in which selfish and misbehaving nodes are detected after aggregation of appropriate evidence from different watchdogs. Advantage: As per the simulation results, the proposed 2-phase watchdog based approach provides improved detection rate and reduction in false positive and selfish nodes in the network, without hindering the QOS and network stability. Disadvantage: Only capable of addressing selfish and misbehaving nodes performing actions for their own benefits like over speeding, packet dropping, etc. A watchdog based approach is used in [24] for the detection of nodes with greedy behavior in VANET by making use of input short periodic traffic traces. The proposed algorithm is based on the combination of linear regression, statistical method, and watchdog based IDS. Linear regression method is used for differentiating between a normal network and a network under attack. The complete working of the proposed algorithm is explained in Fig. 12. Initially, the short period traffic traces are collected, and the correlation coefficient is calculated. If the value of the Correlation coefficient of linear regression straight is not close to one, then there exist chances of greedy behavior in the network and then the watchdog is used for the monitoring of the network on the basis of metrics especially for VANET like transmission time, no. of login attempts of each node, average connection duration. Advantage: The proposed algorithm is passive, non-resource hungry, doesn't require any modification in MAC layer and can be executed by any node in the network. Disadvantage: Percentage of greedy nodes in the network for evaluation is not mentioned. Also, the approach is suitable for the detection of greedy nodes only, and it is not mentioned what type of greedy behavior this approach was used for evaluation. Future: Use of the proposed algorithm for the [23] where a protocol independent watchdog component is claimed to be produced. A simple technique in which packets received by the node under consideration from its neighbor for forwarding are counted and checked how many packets are actually been forwarded by the node is used for the detection of malicious nodes. However, factors like collision and signal noise can also lead to packets dropping. So the authors have introduced a tolerance threshold in which packet loose tolerance is defined. Node is declared as malicious if the packet dropping by a node exceeds the tolerance threshold. Devaluation technique is used in the proposed system for reducing the false negative problem that consists in decrease the weight of the oldest received packets along the time, and thus their influence of considered packets in the computation of the tolerance threshold. Advantage: Tolerance threshold and devaluation are proposed for reducing the false positive and false negative in the detection system. Disadvantage: This approach is designed to detect black hole attack only. Also, the watchdog techniques involve working of nodes in promiscuous mode to listen to the other node`s traffic. This can lead to privacy and security issues, and also this approach can introduce unnecessary traffic into the network affecting the whole network performance. Future Scope: In a future version of the proposed system, authors aim to improve the tolerance threshold by making it more dynamic and use Bayesian filtering to reduce the false positive and improve the detection of the watchdog.

A DMN algorithm has been proposed in [38] that improves the existing DMV algorithm by selecting optimal verifiers for the malicious nodes detection. The proposed approach is nodecentric in which suitable verifiers satisfying certain threshold values are selected that monitors the other nodes for packet drops and duplicate packet injection. Parameters like distrust value, load and distance are used for the election of verifiers. Verifier mark a node as malicious whose distrust value in terms of packet drop and packet duplication exceeds the specific threshold to reduce the false positives. Advantage: Instead of using all trustworthy nodes for monitoring purpose, only selective nodes satisfying certain threshold values are used as watchdogs. This helps in network resource utilization and thus improves the network performance. Disadvantage: Only work with packet dropping and packet duplication injection attack. Also monitoring the traffic of other nodes can cause congestion and privacy issues. This proposal has a probability of producing a lot of false positives as node dropping packets because of some problem will also be considered as malicious. Also, the node density considered for evaluation of the proposed system is considerably low. The threshold value for marking the node as malicious is not mentioned anywhere in the article by the authors. Future Scope: Optimization techniques like PSO, GA, etc. can be used for the selection of verifiers in the proposed algorithm for the improvement in detection. A technique for malicious node prevention can be used in the near future. Along with it, deployment of the proposed method in real scenarios will be done to test its performance in real traffic.

Authors in [25] have proposed a data-centric approach in contrast to existing entity-specific approaches in which instead of looking for misbehaving nodes, this approach works by identifying the information as good and bad. False information initiated by misbehaving nodes are identified by monitoring the alerts generated by the node and their corresponding actions. On identification of false information sent by a node, Watchdogs send this information to the respective CA which imposes fine on the culprit node instead of isolating it from the network. The imposition of penalty on the node is done to discourage the node from sending the false messages and eventually reduces the network load consumption required in node credentials revoking process. ECMV approach is used in the proposed scheme for the authentication purpose. Advantage: This approach does not make use of any voting or majority decisions for detection of false information and misbehaving nodes making this approach free from Sybil attacks. Also, a new reward and penalty system is used instead of isolating the misbehaving nodes. This reduces the total computation and communication wastage involved in revoking and isolating the credentials of misbehaving nodes.

div.head: Disadvantage:
div.p: The technique of only using fine as a penalty on the culprit nodes can work for greedy nodes only and cannot for malicious nodes whose aim is to harm others. Simulation parameters and simulation scenario including the type of simulator used is not mentioned clearly. Future Scope: Realtime simulation of the proposed system will be done in the future.

div.head: 3) Anomaly based IDS Approaches
div.p: Anomaly based IDSs compares the system`s activity at some instant of time with the normal behavior of the system. In case of any event deviating from normal behavior is considered as malicious and alert is generated for the same. This approach is capable of dealing with newer and out of rule attacks also. However, this approach has some drawbacks and challenges also associated with it in the way that any normal event even if it is not matching with the normal behavior of the network will be marked as malicious. And thus setting up of the optimal normal behavior is an important challenge for reducing false positives rate [65,66].

For setting up the normal behavior profile of the network, statistical and machine learning approaches are used mostly but imposes a heavy burden on resource constrained nodes. So anomaly based approaches should consider this in particular.

A version of anomaly based IDS has been proposed by authors in [2] which uses statistical approach and traffic model for the detection of false information attack especially in emergency messages and rogue nodes respectively. This IDS is deployed on every node in the network and using the statistical approach is able to detect as well as contain the damage by taking corrective measures. In order to make the proposed IDS to detect the attack, IDS is trained under normal conditions such that any deviations from that can make the IDS to generate alarms. In the proposed IDS, every node exchanges parameter information like speed, calculated average flow, average density, etc. with other nodes in its vicinity using the Greenshields's model. Since all the vehicles have a parameter value of all other nodes in its vicinity, so each vehicle has the information of all other nodes. Mean value is calculated by each vehicle and is compared with other vehicle`s mean. All the vehicles in the same vicinity will calculate almost same flow value (mean). Then t-test is applied to detect false value reported by any malicious vehicle. If there is a significant difference between received value and vehicle`s own calculated value, then that node is monitored and accepts its data temporarily. The t-test is applied to the further parameters received by that node. If the value of the t-test is within a given acceptance value, then the data is accepted else rejected. If data is rejected, then that node is marked as a rogue node and further messages from that node are rejected. Advantage: The proposed IDS is able to detect the fake message injection attack by just analyzing the data without making use of any trust or reputation based techniques. Also, this IDS is also efficient to detect the Sybil attack in which nodes are faking their locations. The proposed IDS is independent of any infrastructure like RSU or any expensive hardware. Disadvantage: This approach fails to detect the rogue node when the rogue node coordinates and modifies (increases or decreases) the parameter value to make the received flow value equal to the calculated values. In that case, there will be no anomaly, and the proposed IDS will not be able to detect the rogue nodes. Also, the overhead of Proposed IDS increases with increase in a number of rogue nodes. Future: In future, this IDS will be extended to detect other attacks in VANET like DOS, fake location reporting or location spoofing attacks.

A Deep Neural Network (DNN) based IDS has been proposed by authors in [5] for enhancing the security of vehicular based network like CAN network. In proposed DNN based IDS, suitable feature vectors for attack detection are extracted from vehicular network packets which are then used for training the proposed DNN based IDS. So the trained DNN based IDS checks every packet for maliciousness and thus identifies and report any malicious attack on the vehicle. Deep learning techniques like initiating the parameters via unsupervised pre-training of deep belief network (DBN) is used in the proposed IDS for enhancing the detection accuracy. All the CAN broadcasted CAN packets are monitored and analyzed by the proposed IDS for attack detection. The proposed IDS is tested for CAN bus networks, and the traffic for simulation is generated using Open Car Test-Bed and OCTANE packet generator. 200,000 packets are generated for the simulation out of which 70 % packets was used for training the IDS and rest 30% was used for testing purpose. The proposed IDS`s performance was evaluated and compared with other machine learning techniques like SVM, ANN, etc. on the basis of security evaluation parameters like false positive rate, false negative rate and detection rate and simulation results claim that the proposed IDS provides real-time response to the attack and significantly improve the detection accuracy in CAN. Advantage: Proposed IDS Scheme uses deep learning technique for improving the capability and the detection accuracy of ANN. Limitation: No information regarding simulation parameters are provided. Also, there is no information regarding the type of attack considered for evaluation the IDS is provided.

Similarly, another anomaly based IDS solution named CEAP has been proposed by authors in [8]. CEAP is a multi-decision intelligent anomaly based IDS that is designed to cope with the hurdles of security challenges in VANET. CEAP uses SVM for identification and categorization of vehicles on the road as cooperative or malicious. To cope with high mobility problem in VANET, Clustering protocol called QOS-OLSR is used which maintains the cluster stability and considers the mobility metrics of vehicles during clusters formation. CEAP consists of four phases: a) Data collection, in which certain node including CH acts as watchdogs and continuously monitors the behavior of the MPR nodes and checks whether the MPR is actually forwarding the packets or not. If not, then that MPR is considered temporary Malicious, b) Data Exchange, in which all the watchdogs in the same cluster exchange their finding with each other to arrive at some decision, c) Data Analysis, which is used to enhance the detection accuracy of CEAP in which SVM is used for confirming and classifying the suspected MPR and finally d) Data Propagation, in which information regarding the malicious MPR is propagated to all the other nodes in the network. Packet dropping attack is considered for evaluation of proposed IDS scheme. VanetMobiSim is used as traffic simulator and MATLAB for implementation of network related algorithms. CEAP performance was compared with other existing IDS solutions, and it outperforms them in terms of false positive rate, accuracy and detection time. Advantage: Proposed IDS reduces the training set size of SVM by restricting the data collection, storage, analysis and forwarding to only selective nodes only. Limitation: Cluster Head disseminates the suitable information regarding the malicious node to nodes in other clusters. But there may be the probability of cluster head also being malicious. This scenario is not considered in the article, and it is assumed that the Cluster head will always be non-malicious. Future: In a future version of CEAP, the probability of all the involved nodes including Cluster head, MPR and normal nodes to act maliciously will be considered. Such scenario requires a fully distributed model independent of the behavior of any nodes. Another future direction is the use of reward and penalty system to motivate the cooperative nodes and punish the malicious nodes. Also, a future version of CEAP can be extended to classify a malicious node based on the type of attack it is performing.

Another hierarchical anomaly based IDS has been proposed by authors in [45] for BUSNET in which bus nodes are designated as cluster heads which collect the routing control and data messages from all the vehicles and forward them to the access points deployed along the RSUs. Using this information, access points get a global picture of the whole network and detects the attacks occurring in the network by analyzing the data flow. For enabling the anomaly based IDS to detect deviations in the network behavior, the neural network is used which using learning process gets to know about the normal network behavior. After the training of the neural network based IDS, it becomes capable and detects the malicious attacks by analyzing the network control messages and data packets in real time. In case of any deviations, an alarm is generated. DOS attack is used for testing the performance of the proposed IDS. Advantage: The proposed IDS claims to provide low false positives. Disadvantage: The proposed IDS is not able to tell the type of attack taking place. It just generates an alarm whenever the behavior value exceeds the threshold value.

Similar anomaly based IDS has been proposed by authors in [43] in which authors have come up with another anomaly based IDS solution that uses Feed-forward neural network (FFNN) and support vector machine (SVM) for the providing protection against the grey hole and rushing attacks. Initially, traffic is generated using the SUMO mobility generator which is fed to the network simulator for the generation of trace files. The generated trace file consists of both normal and abnormal behavior. Then suitable features are extracted from the trace file using Proportional Overlapping Score (POS) which are then fuzzified and are used to train both SVM based and FFNN based IDS. The complete flow is explained using Fig. 13. Simulation results show that the FFNN based IDS is more efficient compared to the SVM based IDS. Apart from detection of aforementioned attacks, proposed IDS scheme consists of a novel response system that automatically puts the infected vehicles into the safe mode to prevent the other vehicles from getting infected and to protect the lives of other drivers. Advantage: Proportional Overlapping Score (POS) is used for extracting valuable features from the available features set in trace file which considerably improves the detection accuracy of the proposed IDS. Disadvantage: Node density for evaluating the performance of the proposed IDS is kept very less.

Same above author in [44] uses Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) and Quadratic Discriminant Analysis (QDA) for the detection of DOS and black hole attack in VANET. First, the malicious behavior is generated by editing the AODV routing protocol. Then mobility is generated using SUMO and which is fed to the network simulator NS2 for generation of trace files. The trace file contains some useful features which are then used to train and test the proposed IDS. The proposed system is trained and tested using LDA and QDA to differentiate between normal and abnormal behavior. The complete flow of the proposed work is shown in Fig. 14. Advantage: The advantage of the proposed IDS over incumbent security systems is that it detects the attack before it causes significant damage. Also, the proposed IDS is not dependent on any expensive hardware and RSUs. Disadvantage: Number of nodes on which the proposed IDS is tested is kept very less. Also, two separate techniques, i.e. LDA and QDA are used and applied separately on a dataset for training and testing of IDS which can lead to false positives and ambient results. Future: To use RSU deployed IDS and also the use of AI techniques like k-Nearest Neighbor Algorithm (k-NN) for enhancing the security of the VANET.

Another lightweight anomaly based IDS optimized and inspired by dolphin behavior has been proposed by authors in [67] in which dolphin swarm optimization is used for enhancing the performance of the IDS in terms of detection time, false positive rate and detection rate. The Proposed anomaly based system claims to provide higher performance than the existing compared security frameworks. Advantage: This IDS makes use of dolphin swarm behavior of hunting for the detection of intrusions. This IDS also uses the concept of multi-cluster head, thus reducing the overburdening of Cluster Heads (CH) in dense network scenarios. Also, this IDS scheme claims to achieve all three goals of security i.e. Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability. Future Scope: Deployment of this multicluster head based Dolphin swarm optimized IDS along with other proactive honeypot solutions for enhanced performance.

div.head: 4) Hybrid detection based IDS Approaches
div.p: Hybrid based IDS utilizes the power of both Anomaly based IDS and Signature based IDS for detection of malicious nodes. The human-created attack patterns in the form of rules are clubbed with the anomaly based IDS technique to form an enhanced version of IDS called as Hybrid IDS. Hybrid IDS to some extent is believed to deal with known attacks as well as the attacks whose signature are not defined by the administrator.

A hybrid based IDS is proposed in [10] in which anomaly based IDS is incorporated using artificial neural networks (ANN) for the detection of DOS attacks in VANET. Network behavior and features stored as trace file are used by the ANN for the detection of malicious nodes performing DOS attack. Drawback: Performance of the proposed system is not compared with other existing IDS. Also, the proposed system is evaluated on only 30 nodes which are very less when compared with other existing approaches and real-time scenarios. Also, no description of misuse based IDS is given anywhere in the whole article.

Same authors in [13] have come with another hybrid based IDS approach but this time for the detection malicious nodes performing black hole attack. The earlier approach has low detection rate and high positive rate, so to improve the accuracy and detection rate, fuzzification on features selected via Proportional Overlapping Scores method (POS) is done which is then further used for the training of ANN. IDS deployment is done on the nodes instead of RSUs for the prevention of attacks in no RSU zone also. Advantage: Using POS, the training features set size is reduced, and only optimal features are selected from available features. Disadvantage: Number of nodes in the simulation is kept only 40, and no comparison of the proposed system with the existing systems is done.

Another hybrid based IDS has been proposed by authors in [7] which uses Proportional Overlapping Score (POS) for fetching of optimal and suitable features from available features in Kyoto Benchmark Dataset. Back Propagation Neural Network (BPNN) is used for the detection of DOS attacks in VANET using the training set obtained from the POS. Proposed neural based IDS are deployed on all the vehicles for the detection. Advantage: The proposed system work by reducing the redundant and not-required features which improve the detection capability and reduces the false positive rate. Disadvantage: This approach is capable of addressing the DOS attacks only. Also, the performance of the proposed system is not compared with any other existing security framework. Information like Simulator used, no. of nodes, and other simulation parameters are missing.

AECFV is another hybrid based IDS introduced in [14] that aims to defend the VANET environment from intruders and malicious users. AECFV provides defense against critical attacks like wormhole, selective forwarding, packet dropping, packet duplication and Sybil attack. AECFV consists of three main intrusion detection agents: LIDS (Local Intrusion Detection System) deployed on each node in a cluster, GIDS (Global Intrusion Detection System) deployed on Cluster Head (CH) of every cluster, and GDS (Global Decision System) positioned at every Road Side Unit (RSU). LIDS uses the signature based detection approach for attaining high accuracy and low false positives. GIDS uses hybrid detection approach (rule based and anomaly based using SVM) for the detection and mitigation of threats from the network. GDS agent is used for maintaining and tracking the trust level of each node in the network. Advantage: AECFV outperforms other compared security frameworks in terms detection accuracy, false positive and detection time. Disadvantage: Malicious node detected by LIDS are sent for confirmation to GIDS which can add an extra delay in detection. Future Work: To deploy and implement AECFV in the real working environment and to compare the simulation and experimental results.

Authors in [16] have proposed a lightweight hybrid IDS for the detection of message injection attack in CAN network. Signature based detection engine is used in the detection of common attacks while anomaly based detection engine is employed for detection of message injection attack by analyzing the message frequency. Three variations of message injection attack viz. a) message injection of single CAN ID, b) message injection of multiple CAN IDs and c) mass injection of CAN messages leading to DOS attack is detected using the proposed IDS. So if IDS finds that the CAN message which is a broadcast message is sent in a time interval less than the set threshold, then that message is marked as malicious. For evaluation, K-car is used as a testing vehicle and KVASER CAN interface is used for connecting CAN bus. Advantage: Proposed IDS is lightweight and require less computational power. Also simulation result of shows that proposed IDS requires less detection time and produces 0 % false positives. Limitation: The proposed system is capable of detecting only 3 version of message injection attacks, i.e. single CAN ID injection, multiple CAN ID injection and mass injection (DOS) in CAN network. Also, there may arise some situations when the CAN warning broadcast message has to be sent frequently, then this IDS will lead to false alarms. Future Work: As future of this work, CAN message sequence will be analyzed for the detection of any irregularity in messages. However, analyzing the message sequence require more computational power but at the same time will improve the detection accuracy of the IDS.

div.head: 5) Cross-layer based IDS
div.p: From the survey conducted, one important loophole that is found in IDS for VANET is that most of the proposed works focusses only on a single specific layer of VANET without considering the other layers. This is one of the important reason for low performance and detection capability of the available IDS approaches. It may happen that the IDS deployed at application layer detects the threats of application layer only, neglecting attack from other layers. So in cross-layer IDS, IDS agent is deployed on multiple layers of IDS for the detection of different threats designed for different layers. Detection results and event logs from different layers are gathered to arrive at a decision.

A modular cross-layer based IDS using context information and knowledge from different layers and different sources like GPS, radar, and sensors along with the knowledge from applications with the aim to enhance the existing security in VANETs has been presented in [1]. The proposed approach is not anomaly based nor signature based IDS. Events from the different layer and from different identities are combined to detect the anomaly and intrusion in the network. Every node will be equipped with specialized modules for collecting audit data on different layers. A local decision module receives continuously audit data summaries from the other modules and analyses them with the aid of additional information, available from other non-network devices, such as GPS, sensors, and radar (side channel data or context data). Various other modules apart from central decision modules like network monitoring modules which is in charge of collecting communication data within node`s transmission range, application evaluation module responsible for evaluation of safety warning messages using the knowledge from applications along with sensor data provided by the context information module is used in the proposed IDS and is shown in Fig. 15. Limitations: Only the theoretical proposal of the cross-layer IDS has been given by the authors. No simulation and practical implementation of the proposed approach has been provided. Future: As an enhancement to the proposed IDS, application knowledge and information from location aided routing and addressing will be combined. Also, the proposed system will be enhanced to detect the safety warning message arriving from different directions and to make the system capable of detecting the malicious nodes spoofing their locations. Also, a certain level of trust is required among the nodes participating in cooperative decision making. So in the near future, dynamic trust establishment between the communicating nodes will be used.

Another cross-layer based IDS has been proposed by authors in [4] which aims to deal with black hole and denial of service attack targeting the QOS-OLSR in order to improve the detection rate of existing Watchdog based solutions in VANET. In the proposed security detection mechanism, separate threat detector has been proposed for different layers and then integrating the results of each detector for efficient mitigation of black hole attack as shown in Fig. 16. The proposed Crosslayer based IDS uses two detection scheme that allows the information exchange between two and three layers respectively. The first detection mechanism allows the information to be exchanged among physical and network layers while the second detection mechanism used in the proposed IDS allows information exchange between physical, MAC and network layer for efficient and accurate detection. Intrusion detector in physical layer consists of a signature key based detector where each legitimate nodes are assigned a signature key. Each watchdog node uses this signature key and maximum likelihood test to test whether the received signal is from a malicious or cooperative node. On detecting that the signal is from the malicious node, then that signal is dropped else the signal is pass to the next layer i.e. network layer for further detection confirmation. In network layer, the signal marked as malicious is further validated using the implemented cooperative watchdog mechanism to further test the maliciousness of the received signal. Depending only on one detection mechanism like of physical layer can lead to false positives because of factors like high noise and physical layer channel interference. This multiple layer defense reduces the false positives and improves the detection accuracy. Finally, in the MAC Layer detection, the ratio of the number of RTS packets sent to the number of RTS packets received among all the neighbors is computed. In case of any discrepancy, it is indicated that the packet loss is due to the collision and not due to an intrusion. Also, the watchdogs in the same cluster and monitoring nodes from other layers cooperate with each other to exchange information and to arrive at a unified final decision. Disadvantage: Proposed approach is designed to tackle a single attack i.e. blackhole attack only. Also, the number of nodes in simulations is kept to only 60 which is considerably less compared to other solutions. Also although the proposed IDS provides high detection rate and low false positive rate but authors has not considered detection time which is an important parameter for highly delay sensitive network like VANETs. Future: Application and MAC layers attacks like broadcast transmission leading to DOS attack will be considered. Also for enhancing the capability of Proposed Cross-layer IDS, the authors plan to adopt a reputation based solution in which each monitoring node will be configured with a reputation based on its performance.

div.head: 6) Honeypot based Proactive IDS
div.p: A honeypot based proactive IDS has been proposed in [68] for dealing with selfish nodes performing selfish activities for saving their resources and other benefits. Various variations of selfish nodes such as energy based, speed based, memory based, etc. exist in literature with different solutions for their mitigation. In this proposed work, energy based selfish vehicular nodes which drops the packets once its residual energy becomes less than 50 %, are addressed.

The proposed Honeypot Selfishness Detection (HPSD) makes use of bait concept for the detection of the selfish nodes. In this approach, once any vehicle drops the packet then it is added to the suspicion selfish node list, and then the bait based honeypot approach is performed on the nodes present in the suspicion list. In normal AODV routing protocol, if any node has to send a packet to some other node in the network, the routing path is created first in which first the source node`s routing table is checked for the presence of path to the destination. If the path is available, then the source node uses that path and sends the packet directly. But in other case when no path is available, source node broadcasts the RREQ packet to all its neighbor nodes. In normal scenario, the cooperative node rebroadcasts to its neighbors until the path to the destination is not found. Since the source node is also the 1-hop neighbor of all its neighboring nodes so it will also receive the same RREQ packet sent by it. So every time the source node checks the character of its neighbor nodes using the above concept of receiving back RREQ packet from its neighbors. In case of any missing RREQ packet from any of its neighbors, then that node is added to the suspicion list and source node sends the bait RREQ packet to that suspicious node. If a suspicious node drops that bait RREQ packet, then that node is marked as suspicious, and all path through that detected suspicious nodes is then deleted. The complete working of the HPSD is explained using the flowchart shown in Fig. 17. Advantage: This approach improves the packet delivery ratio and end-to-end delay. With this approach, the usefulness of honeypot mechanism for the detection of malicious nodes is seen which can be extended and enhanced for better detection rate. Disadvantage: This approach introduces extra unnecessary traffic and overhead into the network by making use of multiple fake bait message for the detection of selfish nodes. Also, this approach is used for the detection of energy based selfish node only. Future Scope: This concept of honeypot based IDS for the detection of selfish nodes can be extended and enhanced for the detection of other known and unknown attacks also.

div.head: C. Validation Strategy
div.p: Validation strategy means how a proposed system is validated for its accuracy and correctness within the defined objectives. This checks whether the proposed model is working as expected and providing the desired level of accurateness or not. There exist various validation strategies for testing the performance and accuracy of a proposed model. In this review article, to check which IDS scheme for VANETs is providing the desired level of results, these IDS schemes are checked for the type of validation strategies being used by them. Each validation strategy has its own limitations and benefits. This categorization of IDS in VANET by validation strategies will help in evaluating the maturity level of IDS in VANET. For validation purposes, following set of validation techniques mentioned by [69] are being used in our survey: a) Empirical: use of empirical methods like use of dedicated physical testbed for evaluation b) Simulation: use of simulation methods using network and traffic simulators. c) Theoretical: use of theoretical arguments and concepts to prove the results. d) None: no validation strategies are employed From the total of 24 reviewed papers, we have found that 4 papers used the empirical technique as validation strategy for the validation of their proposed models [5,11,16,23]. In all the above work, authors developed and used a dedicated physical testbed formed by the combination of VANET specific software and hardware like CAN bus, and sensors to evaluate their proposals.

18 [2, 4, 7-9, 13, 14, 18, 20-22, 24, 25, 29, 38, 43-45] out of 24 reviewed papers have been found using simulation as their validation strategy, and each of them found to be using different network simulators and traffic generators. OMNet [2], MATLAB [4,8,29], NS-2 [11,13,38,[43][44][45], NS-3 [14,20,24], V2X Simulation Runtime Infrastructure (VSimRTI) [18] are the network simulators used in the simulation for the validation of the proposed IDS in VANET while for realistic traffic generation, traffic generators like SUMO [2,13,14,18,20,24,43,44], VACAMOBIL [2], VANET Mobisim [4,8,9,29], MOVE [13,43,44], VANET Simulator [21], VDTNSim [22] is used. Besides, it is unclear which network simulator and traffic generator were used in [7,9,21,22,25,38,45]. Fig. 18 and 19 show performance comparison of some IDS for VANET on the basis of validation parameters like detection time, detection rate, and false positive rate. Finally, one work was found with no validation efforts [1] and one research article [35] found to be using theoretical validation strategy.

From the above studies and discussions, we have come to a conclusion that no fix validation strategy is available and used for IDS in VANET. Every study is using its own different validation strategy. Even for simulation based validation, different simulators, both network and traffic, are being used with no valid reason for their choice for similar attacks like DOS. Also in some papers it is not clearly mentioned which attack the author is considering to test their proposed IDS model while in some papers, the proposed model is compared with other existing techniques using some other attacks or without mentioning the attack considered. Also, the percentage of malicious nodes considered for evaluation purpose plays a crucial role, and in most of the articles [4, 5, 7, 9, 11, 16, 18, 21, 23-25, 44, 45], this parameter is not mentioned clearly.

div.head: VII. ISSUES, CONCERNS AND FUTURE RESEARCH DIRECTIONS
A. Drawbacks of Existing IDS
div.p: In this section, drawbacks and challenges in the deployment of IDS for VANET are enumerated from the exhaustive literature survey and is presented.

div.head: 1) Real World Deployment and testing
div.p: There is a need of a real-world deployment of IDS in real traffic scenarios for the purpose of evaluating the performance of proposed IDS. Although existing IDS schemes are available with their simulation and statistical analysis but that schemes need to be tested in real and unideal traffic environment to prove their applicability and performance.

div.head: 2) Attack Specific IDS:
div.p: Existing IDS in literature are designed for certain attacks only and are capable of addressing one or two attacks only. So it is a difficult task to club these existing IDS proposals addressing different individual attacks. So researchers are required to propose a generalized IDS addressing all the major attacks possible in VANET environment.

div.head: 3) Requirement of Lightweight and Resource Friendly IDS
div.p: Deployment of IDS in VANET is done either on RSU or nodes which are movable vehicles. Vehicles in VANET are mostly resource constraint and deployment of heavy and complex IDS can hinder the performance of the VANET network. So there is a need of IDS that maintains a balance between performance, effectiveness, and detection, before their deployment.

div.head: 4) Pros and Cons of proposed schemes are missing
div.p: After analyzing the papers, we found that the pros and cons of each proposed technique are missing. Also, the reason for the choice of different parameters like simulator, validation strategy, deployment location, detection technique is not mentioned.

div.head: 5) Data Set:
div.p: The attacks in VANET are enormous and emerging. Existing data set used in literature like KDD-99 [70] are outdated, and attacks specifically for VANET are missing in them. So there is a dire requirement of a specialized dataset containing pattern of most of the attacks of VANET. This data set can help researchers in testing their proposed IDS detection performance against various attacks.

div.head: 6) Deployment Location in VANET
div.p: The position of deployment of IDS in VANET plays a very major role from performance and resource utilization point of view. Deploying an IDS in every component of VANET and on every node can affect the performance of the network. So there is a great need to decide the location of IDS from performance and security point of view. Deploying of IDS in every node and RSU can help in achieving better network security as all the information flowing in the network will be analyzed in this way. However, this deployment strategy can add unnecessary overhead on both network as well as on the nodes hindering the network performance. Also, it will eat the limited resources of the nodes causing them to malfunction.

div.head: 7) Inability in detection and mitigation of Zero Day attacks:
div.p: Existing IDS approaches in literature are concerned with detection and mitigation of existing attacks only. But as the security is an emerging topic and new threats keep on adding, so there is a need for a security strategy and framework to deal with these new Zero-day attacks. This can be achieved by making use of various pre-attack detection straggles like the use of honeypots.

div.head: 8) Inability in Beforehand Prediction of Threats:
div.p: Almost all of the existing IDS based solutions in literature for VANETs and VANETs Cloud have their focus on the detection of current attacks only and they lack in predicting the attacks beforehand. There should be a framework that can predict the attacks beforehand. The incorporation and introduction of Intrusion Prediction based System (IPS) capable of sensing the attacks beforehand will definitely enhance the security of VANETs to a greater extent. One such Intrusion Prediction System (IPS) work is available in the literature [71] which can serve as a good base for developing more such frameworks for enhancing the VANETs security.

div.head: VIII. PROPOSED HONEYPOT BASED INTRUSION DETECTION SYSTEM FOR VANET
div.p: From the exhaustive review conducted above, we have come to a conclusion that each type of IDS, whether it is signature based or anomaly based IDS, have some challenges and drawbacks associated with them in VANETs. VANET is an emerging network and newer attacks keep on adding, and almost all the existing IDS in literature are designed for specific and one or two attacks. So there is a need of security framework that should be capable of automatically handling the unknown and zero-day attacks.

We have seen the possibility of using honeypot based IDS in VANETs in the above-conducted survey. Although almost negligible work is done in the use of honeypot mechanism for IDS. But honeypot mechanism has already proved its worth as detection system in traditional networks.

So keeping the aforementioned challenges and requirement in mind, we have proposed a Bait based Intrusion Detection System also called as Honeypot based IDS (HPIDS) that is made capable of dealing with both existing attacks as well as unknown and zero-day attacks in VANETs.

In our proposed HPIDS scheme, every node in the network will be equipped with signature based IDS for the detection of known and common in-rule based threats. The reason for the choice of Signature based IDS in our proposed framework over other IDS types is some of its advantages in VANETs like less complex and less time incurring threat detection logic, less false positive, high accuracy for in rules attacks, etc. Now for the detection of out of rule attacks, few node in the network will act as bait or honeypot to tempt the malicious nodes to attack them. Whenever the malicious node performs some attack on the honeypot nodes, their activity will get logged and also the type of attack pattern used by them will also get saved by the honeypot node. Afterwards, the corresponding attack signature is generated by the honeypot node and is transferred to the other normal node`s signature based IDS ruleset making them capable of detecting attacks which were not in their database. On receiving the newly created attack signature rule, each node checks their existing ruleset for the presence of any similar rules. If the signature rule received is already present in the node`s ruleset then the received rule is discarded else the rule is added to the existing rule database of the node.
Fig. 20 graphically illustrates the working of our proposed HPIDS scheme.

div.head: A. Advantages of Proposed HPIDS Framework 1) Zero-Day attacks Detection
div.p: Proposed HPIDS framework is a combination of both IDS and honeypot making it capable of detecting both known as well as zero-day attacks. Thus, making it more secure and robust. Honeypot module deployed in it will be used for the detection of zero-day attacks while the IDS module will be for the detection of known attacks.

div.head: 2) A more Generalized and non-attack specific Framework
div.p: Most of the existing IDS based and other security frameworks in literature for VANETs and VANETs Clouds as studied in above study have considered and are capable of dealing with only one or two attacks. The scope of proposed HPIDS is not made specific and limited to one or two attacks but can cover general attacks also which was a problem with existing IDS based solutions covering one or two attacks.

div.head: 3) Lightweight and Less Resource Hungry
div.p: Considering the resource constraint issues in VANET, proposed HPIDS is lightweight in terms of less resource consumption for its working.

div.head: 4) High Detection Rate
div.p: Introduction of honeypot modules in the nodes along with the IDS has increased the detection rate of the attacks as both known as well as unknown attacks are covered by this framework.

div.head: 5) Auto-generation and distribution of Zero-day attack`s signature to IDS nodes with zero human intervention.
div.p: Information and training regarding any out of scope attacks logged by the honeypot module are auto-generated by the honeypot and is then circulated to all the IDS for making them capable of detecting that unknown attacks.

div.head: B. Important Considerations for Proposed HPIDS Framework
div.p: Important considerations that need to be taken care during the design and deployment of Proposed HPIDS framework are:

div.head: 1) Choice of Honeypot Node
div.p: Choice of honeypot node plays a crucial role in the efficient working of our proposed HPIDS framework. The task of honeypot node can be assigned either to a) RSUs or b) Nodes. The decision of making RSUs as honeypot node contains both benefits as well as some major shortcomings. Since as explained above, the honeypot node has to perform some resource consuming tasks like logging of malicious node`s activities, automatic generation of rules against the logged attack patterns, etc. so only nodes rich in resources should be made as a honeypot. In this way, RSU is the best contender for acting as Honeypot.

But the RSUs are not uniformly deployed, and in remote areas where there are limited RSU deployed, the decision of making RSUs as honeypot will fail. So Cluster Head (CH) or nodes with high resources in term of energy, storage, Bandwidth, Computation Capability should be elected as Honeypot. For the same task of finding among the nodes an optimal honeypot node, Hybrid Fuzzy Multi-Criteria Decision making (HF-MCDM) approach can be used.

div.head: 2) Density of Honeypot Nodes
div.p: Since the VANETs is highly dynamic and changing network where sometimes the traffic becomes highly dense whereas sometimes it becomes very sparse, so optimal number of nodes to be made as Honeypot is another important consideration.

div.head: 3) Choice of IDS to use along with honeypot
div.p: The type of IDS to be deployed on individual nodes is another important factor that requires discussion as every IDS type whether it is signature, anomaly, hybrid or cross-layer based IDS, has its own advantages and shortcomings. But from the above-conducted survey, we found Signature based IDS can be the better choice over the other IDS techniques considering the nature of VANETs.

div.head: IX. CONCLUSION
div.p: VANET and VANET Cloud is a new innovation in the field of Intelligent Transportation System (ITS) with the aim to improve the driving experience, road safety, fuel efficiency, resource utilization, etc. But because of association of VANETs and VANETs Cloud with life critical and delay sensitive network and also because of some inherent features of it, this network is highly prone to attacks by intruders and selfish users. Therefore, a security solution for VANETs and VANETs Cloud need to be developed and focused upon. IDS which has already proved its worth in securing the traditional network is the first choice in enhancing security in VANETs also. But deployment and design of IDS in VANETs and VANET Cloud require special considerations.

In this paper, we have come forward with an in-depth and comprehensive study on IDS and Honeypots based security mechanism for VANET and VANET Cloud technologies for providing pre and post defense against various malevolent attacks. We analyzed and studied 25 research works from 2000 to 2017 that proposed IDS scheme for VANET and VANET Cloud or have used some detection scheme for VANETs that could be a part of an IDS. IDS for VANET and VANET Cloud are studied and categorized on the basis of important attributes like detection mechanism, deployment location and validation strategy in use. Furthermore, the possibility of use of honeypot based solutions for enhancing security in VANET and VANET cloud and for detection of existing and unknown attacks are also analyzed, and an architecture of Honeypot based IDS (HPIDS) has been proposed along with its design and deployment consideration for better detection rate.

On the basis of our study and findings we observed that, although the research on VANET has started in early 2000, security is one among the important area that needs attention for error-free deployment of VANET. IDS based solutions are adopted and proposed by many security researchers, but there are still various issues (e.g. IDS deployment location, IDS architecture, the trade-off between parameters like accuracy, resource consumption, and detection delay) that still need further attention and thus is still incipient. The existing proposed solutions cover only limited attacks and are designed for specific attacks only. Moreover, which detection technique and placement strategy are more optimal for VANET environment is not clear. Finally, it is worth mentioning that validation strategies are not fixed, and different validation techniques and simulators are being used by the researchers.

Also, very less to no work has been done so far on analyzing the deployment possibilities and possible challenges in the use of IDS based techniques in VANET Cloud Environment for malicious attack detections.

From this study and results, we hope that the budding and active researchers working in this area can benefit. As a future research, following issues and challenges in deployment of IDS in VANET and VANET Cloud can be stressed on 1) choice of optimal deployment location for improved detection and enhanced network performance; 2) detection of zero-day and unknown attacks; 3) creation of up-to-date dataset for newer attack detection capability testing; 4) to find pros and cons of various detection schemes and deployment strategies; 5) to improve and use of some generalized validation strategies; 6) to develop some auto alert detection and response management systems; 7) beforehand prediction of occurrence of Intrusions.

Design Consideration for IDS in VANET
VANET is a highly mobile, dynamic and distributed network
with no fixed boundaries. Such networks are highly prone to
attacks both insider as well as outsider. So following design
issues and challenges of VANET need to be considered while
designing and deploying the IDS for it.
• High Mobility: Nodes in VANET are fast moving, and
this high mobility can have a huge impact on detection
rate of IDS. So an IDS adaptive to high mobility in
VANET is required.

figure.figDesc: possible types of timing attack in VANET are: a) Node to Node Timing Attack: This type of timing attack is further subcategorized as Simple Node to Node Timing attack and Extended Node to Node Timing attack. The Simple Node to Node Timing attack affects communication which is taking between two nodes i.e. peer to peer communication. The threat level in this type of timing attack is very less as compared to the extended version of the node to node timing attack because only one node is affected by this attack. Consider this scenario in which we have two communicating nodes: A and B and say C is an attacking node. A sends a safety message to B informing it about the accident that took place on the highway and advising it to take the right diversion. But attacker node C intercepts the message and adds a delay of 15 seconds in message causing the node B to go on the path where the accident has taken place. Whereas extended Node to Node Timing attack is more critical because this affects more than one vehicle. This attack targets the vehicles nodes communicating in groups. b) Node to Infrastructure Timing Attack: This type of timing attack is very critical and need to be addressed.
